title: PremiumcryptoHub
author: PremiumcryptoHub
content: A foundation called Taruna Bakti in Bandung, Indonesia has taken the initiative to educate 700 secondary school students in Indonesian secondary schools about Bitcoin.  Maybe that's how Bitcoin is spreading to remote areas around the world.  If these students learn about Bitcoin from an early age, they will grow up to be much more experienced about Bitcoin. After gaining experience with Bitcoin, they can teach other people about Bitcoin.  We have seen news in El Salvador that the President of that country, Nayib Bukele has taken various programs to educate school students in Bitcoin education to spread Bitcoin widely in their country even teaches Bitcoin to students there. This time Indonesia took the initiative.https://x.com/bitcoinindo21/status/1858767829811818777?t=GgHE0regxVx9Ox9z5XC87g&s=19

comments.author: Jawhead999
comments.body: They're too late, we already have Akademi Crypto, a project that mainly for education, mainly about Bitcoin, but in the end most people are in loss because the project now tend to discuss about altcoins and give useless signals. It's quite surprising how they allow to teach about Bitcoin considering most people think it's high risk investment, not to mention the risk of fall to gambling.

comments.author: Russlenat
comments.body: That’s a great initiative, but is there also a focus on educating groups who are more vulnerable to scams, like older people? I love their effort to educate students but I am just wondering how many of them actually use Bitcoin. You know, It’s one thing to hear about it, but if you’re not actively using it then you’re likely to forget it over time. Plus, students are young and primarily focused on their studies, so Bitcoin might not feel immediately relevant to them.That said, I was also surprised by the data showing they rank in the top 5 for the most users. It goes to show that education, in any form, can make a huge difference. Maybe it’s planting seeds that will grow when the time is right for them to be actively using bitcoin. https://plasbit.com/blog/bitcoin-adoption-by-country

comments.body: Quote from: Jawhead999 on November 24, 2024, 02:54:42 PMIt's quite surprising how they allow to teach about Bitcoin considering most people think it's high risk investment, not to mention the risk of fall to gambling. Bitcoin can be used for many purposes, gambling is one of its use cases but if you consider Bitcoin as your investment asset, it is not gambling.Trading can be considered as gambling especially if you trade without knowledge and experience about trading in general and about Bitcoin market in particular. Trading can be seen more like gambling if you trade it with Leverage or Futures markets.If you only spend your money to buy bitcoin, for your investment portfolio, it's not gambling. comments.body: Quote from: PremiumcryptoHub on November 24, 2024, 02:36:47 PMA foundation called Taruna Bakti in Bandung, Indonesia has taken the initiative to educate 700 secondary school students in Indonesian secondary schools about Bitcoin.  Maybe that's how Bitcoin is spreading to remote areas around the world.  If these students learn about Bitcoin from an early age, they will grow up to be much more experienced about Bitcoin. After gaining experience with Bitcoin, they can teach other people about Bitcoin.  We have seen news in El Salvador that the President of that country, Nayib Bukele has taken various programs to educate school students in Bitcoin education to spread Bitcoin widely in their country even teaches Bitcoin to students there. This time Indonesia took the initiative.News like this are definitely what pleases every member of this community, but my question is, what actually are these children being taught about Bitcoin?. Is it the technological (technical) part?, Or the Economical part that has to do with buying/selling and others. It's quite alright that both of these two parts are taught, but I feel school children or any place where such programs are run should know more about Bitcoin as a technology. I believe they don't really need to go indepth in terms of technicality, but at least have ideas on some basic things. The financial part shouldn't be left out of it though. But it's quite unfortunate that my country isn't really pushing for something like this.

comments.author: bitLeap
comments.body: In this era, it is indeed time for any country to be able to expand education related to bitcoin, considering specifically bitcoin because it will provide awareness of the technology and nature of bitcoin. But once again, systematic education that is included in the curriculum is much better than just a seasonal event. These students need to get formal bitcoin education guidance. Because if it is only a cursory and there is no further education, it will not have any effect.

This time Indonesia took the initiative.News like this are definitely what pleases every member of this community, but my question is, what actually are these children being taught about Bitcoin?. Is it the technological (technical) part?, Or the Economical part that has to do with buying/selling and others. It's quite alright that both of these two parts are taught, but I feel school children or any place where such programs are run should know more about Bitcoin as a technology. I believe they don't really need to go indepth in terms of technicality, but at least have ideas on some basic things. The financial part shouldn't be left out of it though. But it's quite unfortunate that my country isn't really pushing for something like this.I'm thinking about this too, many people will be happy with news like this because they think this will make bitcoin more popular and help bitcoin price go higher, and they will get more profit. But if we put ourselves in the shoes of those students' parents, would it be good to teach them about investing and trading right at school? Have these kids ever learned about financial management? If they have never had any financial training or education, teaching them about bitcoin may not be beneficial to them.What if they neglect their studies, use their tuition fees to invest in bitcoin, and even engage in highly leveraged bitcoin trading? Introducing bitcoin to kids too early is like a double-edged sword, it is not as perfect as we think.

comments.author: hugeblack
comments.body: Bitcoin education is good but the content is the key, I see a lot of Bitcoin conferences becoming get rich quick events, memecoins and some scam tokens with projects that promise you a lot of profits with minimal effort. If they were taught the basics of money, saving and how to avoid debt crisis. Taking Bitcoin as an example of cheap international transactions and long term investment, as well as the basics of creating a wallet and avoiding scams would be great.

Now not only Indonesia but also our neighboring country India is slowly progressing in the field of Bitcoin education. Just as the world is moving forward day by day, digital currency is gaining acceptance among people.
